title: 109_s660
content: The "Lumbee Recognition Act" is the short title of this Act. The preamble of the Act of June 7, 1956 is amended by making specific changes to the wording. The Lumbee Indians of North Carolina are descendants of coastal tribes, recognized by the state since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. The Lumbee Tribe, descendants of coastal tribes, have been recognized by the state since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. Congress now acknowledges that the Lumbee Indians should receive full Federal recognition and the benefits that come with it. The Lumbee Tribe, descendants of coastal tribes, have been recognized by the state since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. Congress now acknowledges that the Lumbee Indians should receive full Federal recognition and the benefits that come with it. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to include a new section on recognition. Federal recognition is extended to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, allowing them to receive all laws and regulations applicable to Indian tribes. Non-enrolled Indians in Robeson and adjoining counties can petition for acknowledgment of tribal existence. Eligibility for services and benefits is outlined in the legislation. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for services and benefits provided to Indians. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be on or near a reservation. Verification by the Secretary is required for determining needs and budget. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina members in certain counties are considered near an Indian reservation. The Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services will develop a budget for services after verifying tribal enrollment. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, in consultation with the Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services, will determine needs and budget for eligible services. The tribal roll will be verified for the delivery of Federal services. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina will determine needs and budget for eligible services in consultation with the Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services. The tribal roll, verified for the delivery of Federal services, will define the service population of the Tribe based on membership criteria set out in the Tribe's constitution. The Secretary's verification is limited to confirming compliance with the membership criteria in the Tribe's constitution adopted on November 11, 2000, to be completed within 1 year of enactment. The Tribe seeks to convey fee land to the United States for trust, to be treated as on-reservation trust acquisitions if located in Robeson County, North Carolina. State jurisdiction is addressed. The State of North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on land owned by the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina. The Secretary of the Interior can accept transfers of land from the State to the United States. The Secretary of the Interior may accept transfers of jurisdiction from the State of North Carolina to the United States on behalf of the Lumbee Tribe, with a 2-year waiting period before the transfer takes effect. The Secretary of the Interior can accept jurisdiction transfers from North Carolina to the United States for the Lumbee Tribe, with a 2-year waiting period before it becomes effective. This does not impact the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out the Act.
